column1: Lichtenrade  is a German locality (Ortsteil) within the borough (Bezirk) of Tempelhof-Schöneberg
column2: Berlin. Until 2001 it was part of the former borough of Tempelhof.

column1: The locality was first mentioned in 1375
column2: named Lichtenrode. Autonomous Prussian municipality of the former Teltow district
column3: Lichtenrade was incorporated into Berlin in 1920
column4: with the "Greater Berlin Act". During World War II
column5: a branch of the Sachsenhausen concentration camp was located in this locality. After 1941
column6: prisoners of war from Ukraine were interned in the camp. During the Cold War it was a part of West Berlin bordering with East Germany. Its long boundary with Brandenburg was surrounded by the Berlin Wall from 1961 to 1989.

column1: Located in the southern suburb of Berlin
column2: it is one of the southernmost areas of the city
column3: largely bounded by the Brandenburger municipalities of Schönefeld (Dahme-Spreewald district)
column4: Blankenfelde-Mahlow and Großbeeren (both in Teltow-Fläming district). It borders with the Berliner localities of Marienfelde
column5: Mariendorf and Buckow (this one in the district of Neukölln).
